citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
***An adult female King Charles Cavalier named Ruby (#992813) was licking her lips repeatedly during the inspection.
Her molar teeth were encased in tarter and her gums were swollen. There was a large ulcerated bloody area in her upper
gums on the right side of her mouth. Also, this dog's right eye had a gray, thick discharge. The cornea was blue and
cloudy with red specks of blood. There was a vertical ulcerated area extending the length of the cornea.
***An adult, female King Charles Cavalier named Little Red (#153649) had excessive tarter on most of her teeth. Her red,
swollen gums were receding away from the teeth.
The licensee had not noticed any of these problems and they were not being treated. Teeth and/or gum problems can be
painful, can affect the animal's ability to eat, and can result in tooth loss. Eye problems can progress rapidly, can be
painful, and can result in loss of vision. The licensee must have these dogs examined by a veterinarian, follow the
treatment recommendations, and maintain medical records for review by the inspector.
TO BE CORRECTED BY MARCH 8, 2023.
NOTE: During the inspection, the licensee made appointments for these dogs with a veterinarian.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End Section

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
***An adult female King Charles Cavalier named Ruby (#992813) was licking her lips repeatedly during the inspection.  
Her molar teeth were encased in tarter and her gums were swollen.  There was a large ulcerated bloody area in her upper 
gums on the right side of her mouth.  Also, this dog's right eye had a gray, thick discharge.  The cornea was blue and 
cloudy with red specks of blood.  There was a vertical ulcerated area extending the length of the cornea.   
 
***An adult, female King Charles Cavalier named Little Red (#153649) had excessive tarter on most of her teeth.  Her red, 
swollen gums were receding away from the teeth. 
 
The licensee had not noticed any of these problems and they were not being treated. Teeth and/or gum problems can be 
painful, can affect the animal's ability to eat, and can result in tooth loss.  Eye problems can progress rapidly, can be 
painful, and can result in loss of vision.  The licensee must have these dogs examined by a veterinarian, follow the 
treatment recommendations, and maintain medical records for review by the inspector.   
TO BE CORRECTED BY MARCH 8, 2023. 
NOTE:  During the inspection, the licensee made appointments for these dogs with a veterinarian.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End Section
